Translated: As the lamp - rod in the place of the air without vibration becomes unconscious, the same parable is said of the chitta of the yogi who is orphaned while practicing yoga.

Original: 6.20 When the mind, restrained by the practice of Yoga attains to quietude and when seeing the Self by the self, he is satisfied in his own Self.
Translated: 6.20. The consumption of yoga leads to a state of calming and calming, and to a state of self - satisfaction when one sees oneself.

Original: 6.21 When he (the Yogi) feels that Infinite Bliss which can be grasped by the (pure) intellect and which transcends the senses, and established wherein he never moves from the Reality.
Translated: The happiness which is finite, intuitive and wise, the happiness which the meditator experiences and in which it is situated, never again deviates from the element.

Original: 6.22 Which, having obtained, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; wherein estabished, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.
Translated: 6.22. There is no more profit for him than that which he receives, and he is not distracted by the great adversity in which he stands.

Original: 6.23 Let that be known by the name of Yoga, the severance from union with pain. This Yoga should be practised with determination and with an undesponding mind.
Translated: 6.23. There is a misunderstanding about the coincidence of the two, which should be known as the Yoga. (The Yoga which is the object of the meditation Yoga) The practitioner should practise it with determination without hesitation.

Original: 6.24 Abandoning without reserve all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of the senses by the mind from all sides.
Translated: 6. 2 4. 2. By abandoning all desires arising from the will and subjecting the sense community from all sides by the mind. 6. 2 4. 2.

Original: 6.25 Little by little let him attain to ietude by the intellect held firmly; having made the mind establish itself in the Self, let him not think of anything.
Translated: Shani: Shani: May the patient intellect (the righteous) attain peace; do not think anything else by placing the mind in the spirit.

Original: 6.26 From whatever cause the restless and unsteady mind wanders away, from that let him restrain it and bring it under the control of the Self alone.
Translated: This shaky and unstable mind should be tempered by the causes of its movement and put under the control of the Self, i. e. in the Self.

Original: 6.27 Supreme Bliss verily comes to this Yogi whose mind is ite peaceful, whose passion is ieted, who has become Brahman and who is free from sin.
Translated: Whose mind is contented, who is sinless (Akalmishm) and whose joyfulness (Abstract) is calm, such a yogi who becomes a Brahman has the best happiness.

Original: 6.28 The Yogi, always engaging the mind thus (in the practice of Yoga), freed from sins, easily enjoys the Infinite Bliss of contact with Brahman (the Eternal).
Translated: Thus, the sinless yogi, who practices the Yoga of constant attachment of the mind to the spirit, enjoys the supreme joy of the Brahma contact.

Original: 6.29 With the mind harmonised by Yoga he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.
Translated: 6.29. The Yogi, who has a yogic inner being and is all - visible, sees the soul in all the devils and all the devils in the soul.

Original: 6.30 He who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, he never becomes separated from Me, nor do I become separated from him.
Translated: For him who sees me everywhere and sees all in me, I am not lost (i. e. I am not far off) and he is not separated from me.

Original: 6.31 He who, being established in unity, worships Me Who dwells in all beings, that Yogi abides in Me, whatever may be his mode of living.
Translated: He who stands in the oneness of the soul, standing in all the spirits, praises me, he who is the Yogi in all forms, standing in me.

Original: 6.32 He who, through the likeness of the Self, O Arjuna, sees eality everywhere, be it pleasure or pain, he is regarded as the highest Yogi.
Translated: He who sees all things equal to himself, whether it be happiness or adversity, is regarded as the Supreme Yogi.

Original: 6.33 Arjuna said  This Yoga of eanimity taught by Thee, O Krishna, I do not see its steady continuance, because of the restlessness (of the mind).
Translated: Arjun said, "Honey, this harmonious Yoga, which you said, I do not see its lasting state because of the shaking of the mind.

Original: 6.34 The mind verily is restless, turbulent, strong and unyielding, O Krishna: I deem it as difficult to control it as to control the wind.
Translated: Because, O Krishna, this mind is chaotic and stubborn in nature and strong and firm; I consider it to be too hard to grasp, like the air.

Original: 6.35 The Blessed Lord said  Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is difficult to control and restless; but by practice and by dispassion it may be restrained.
Translated: Sri Bhagwan says, "O Mahabharata, the mind is undoubtedly subject to agitation and hardship; but, O Kuntiputra, it can be subjected by practice and love."

Original: 6.36 I think Yoga is hard to be attained by one of uncontrolled self, but the self-controlled and striving one can attain to it by the (proper) means.
Translated: It is difficult to attain Yoga by a man of unconstrained mind, but it is possible to attain Yoga by means of a man of an independent mind, I believe.

Original: 6.37 Arjuna said  He who is unable to control himself though he has the faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, mee,t O Krishna?
Translated: Arjun said, "O Krishna, whose mind has been driven by Yoga, what is the movement of such an unfinished effort - LRB - destiny - RRB - of such a devout man who does not achieve the perfection of Yoga?

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Is he not corrupted and destroyed on both sides in the way of Brahman, like a scattered cloud?

Original: 6.39 This doubt of mine, O Krishna, do Thou dispel completely; because it is not possible for any but Thee to dispel this doubt.
Translated: You, Krishna, are the only one who is capable of cutting off my suspicion completely; for there is no one else besides you who can cut off this suspicion.

Original: 6.40 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, neither in this world, nor in the next world is there destruction for him; none, verily, who does good, O My son, ever comes to grief.
Translated: 6.40 Sri Bhagwan said, "O Parth, that man is destroyed neither in this world nor in the Hereafter; no good worker gets evil."

Original: 6.41 Having attained to the worlds of the righteous and having dwelt there for everlasting years, he who fell from Yoga is rorn in a house of the pure and wealthy.
Translated: 6.41. The wrong man is born in the house of the purely conducted lord (rich) men, having received the lands of the virtuous and lived there for a long time.

Original: 6.42 Or he is born in a family of even the wise Yogis; verily a birth like this is very difficult to obtain in this world.
Translated: 6.42. Or, (the teacher) births in the tribe of knowledgeable yogis, but such a birth is undoubtedly very rare in this world.

Original: 6.43 Thee he comes in touch with the knowledge acired in his former body and strives more than before for perfection, O Arjuna.
Translated: 6.43. He, Kurundandan, makes even greater efforts to achieve the Yoga of Self - Perfection by acquiring the knowledge that he has acquired there in the former body.

Original: 6.44 By that very former practice he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmic word.
Translated: 6. 44. Because of the same practice, he is drawn to the Yoga of Self - Perfection. He who is merely an enlightened man of Yoga transcends the word Brahman.

Original: 6.45 But the Yogi who strives with assiduity, purified of sins and perfected gradually through many births, reaches the highest goal.
Translated: But a yogi who practices diligently and is cleansed from all sins and is proved by many births, then he gets the supreme speed.

Original: 6.46 The Yogi is thought to be superior to the ascetics and even superior to men of knowledge (obtained through the study of scriptures); he is also superior to men of action; therefore be thou a Yogi, O Arjuna.
Translated: Since the Yogi is superior to the Assams and is considered superior to those who possess knowledge (only in science) and the Yogi is superior to those who practise, be Yogi, O Arjuna.

Original: 6.47 And among all the Yogis he who, full of faith and with his inner self merged in Me, worships Me is deemed by Me to be the most devout.
Translated: 6. 47. Every devout yogi among all yogis who praises me with the spirit of unity in me is the most appreciative of me.

Original: 7.1 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, hear how you shall without doubt know Me fully, with the mind intent on Me, practising Yoga and taking refuge in Me.
Translated: Hear, O Parth, as you know me wholeheartedly, without any doubt, as I practise Yoga in a state of disability and exhaustion.

Original: 7.2 I shall declare to thee in full this knowledge combined with realisation, after knowing which nothing more here remains to be known.
Translated: 7. 2. I will tell you of this knowledge, including science, which there is no more to know here (in the world).

Original: 7.3 Among thousands of men, one perchance strives for perfection; even among those successful strivers, only one perchance knows Me in essence.
Translated: There is no man among the thousands who strive for perfection, and no man among the striving sages knows me in substance.

Original: 7.4 Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect and egoism  thus is My Nature divided eightfold.
Translated: The earth, the water, the fire, the air and the sky and the mind, the intellect and the ego - this is my nature divided into eight types.

Original: 7.5 This is the inferior Prakriti, O mighty-armed (Arjuna); know thou as different from it My higher Prakriti (Nature), the very life-element, by which this world is upheld.
Translated: 7. 5 < s > O Mahabharata! This is the Upra Nature. Know the Para - Nature of My Life, other than this, from which this world is taken.

Original: 7.6 Know that these two (Natures) are the womb of all beings. So I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.
Translated: Know that the homogeneous ghosts originate from these two natures. I am the origin and place of the whole world.

Original: 7.7 There is nothing whatsoever higher than Me, O Arjuna. All this is strung on Me, as clusters of gems on a string.
Translated: 7. 7. < s > O Dhanjay! There is no other thing better than me. It has been poured into me in the whole world like a monk.

Original: 7.8 I am the sapidity in water, O Arjuna; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, sound in ether and virility in men.
Translated: I am in the water, I am in the moon, I am in the sun, I am in all the Vedas, I am in the heavens, I am in the word, and I am in the men.

Original: 7.9 I am the sweet fragrance in the earth and the brilliance in the fire, the life in all beings, and I am the austerity in ascetics.
Translated: 7. 9. I am holy in the earth and strong in the fire; I am life in all the devils and in the ascetics I am ascetic.

Original: 7.10 Know Me, O Arjuna, as the eternal seed of all beings; I am the intelligence of the intelligent; the splendour of the splendid objects am I.
Translated: 7. 10. < s > O Parth, know me alone, the eternal seed of all the devils; I am the intelligence of the wise and the power of the bright.

Original: 7.11 Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in (all) beings, I am the desire unopposed to Dharma, O Arjuna.
Translated: O Bharat Shrestha, I am the desire of the mighty and the power without attachment, and in all the devils I am the opposite of religion, i. e. the righteous work.

Original: 7.12 Whatever beings (and objects) that are pure, active and inert, know that they proceed from Me. They are in Me, yet I am not in them.
Translated: Know all the essential (pure), dynamic (active) and tactical feelings that you are born of me; yet I am not among them, they are in me.

Original: 7.13 Deluded by these Natures (states or things) composed of the three alities of Nature all this world does not know Me as distinct from them and immutable.
Translated: I do not know the non - expendable form beyond these feelings (disorders) generated by the three virtues.

Original: 7.14 Verily, this divine illusion of Mine, made up of the (three) alities (of Nature) is difficult to cross over; those who take refuge in Me alone, cross over this illusion.
Translated: This divine three - fold My Maya is a great double. But those who come to My shelter pass through this Maya.

Original: 7.15 The evil-doers and the deluded who are the lowest of men do not seek Me; they whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.
Translated: 7.15. The evildoers, the foolish, the male men do not shout to me; those who have been deceived by illusion retain the feeling of aसुर.

Original: 7.16 Four kinds of virtuous men worship Me, O Arjuna, and they are the distressed, the seekr of knowledge, the seekr of wealth and the wise, O lord of the Bharatas.
Translated: “O Bharat Shrestha Arjuna! Four kinds of good - doing people (Saturitans) praise me: the Aryans, the Scientists, the Puritans and the Wise. ”

Original: 7.17 Of them the wise, ever steadfast and devoted to the One, excels (is the best); for I am exceedingly dear to the wise and he is dear to Me.
Translated: Among them, too, the most eternal and devout of all is the Wise, for I love him very much and he is my favourite.

Original: 7.18 Noble indeed are all these; but I deem the wise man as My very Self; for, steadfast in mind he is established in Me alone as the supreme goal.
Translated: These are all excellent, however, but the wise is my very nature, as I believe, for the wise, the constant intelligence, is in good condition in me as the best movement.

Original: 7.19 At the end of many births the wise man comes to Me, realising that all this is Vaasudeva (the innermost Self); such a great soul (Mahatma) is very hard to find.
Translated: 7.19. At the end of many births (in one particular birth) I receive the knowledge that 'this is all Vasudeva', a knowledgeable devotee; such a Mahatma is very rare.

Original: 7.20 Those whose wisdom has been rent away by this or that desire, go to other gods, following this or that rite, led by their own nature.
Translated: 7.20. Such men, driven by their own nature and by the desire for special enjoyment, who have been denied knowledge, prostrate themselves to other gods in observance of special rules.

Original: 7.21 Whatsoever form any devotee desires to worship with faith  that (same) faith of his I make firm and unflinching.
Translated: 7.21. Whosoever is a devotee, whosoever desires to worship the form of a deity with faith, I shall establish his faith in the same deity.

Original: 7.22 Endowed with that faith, he engages in the worship of that (form) and from it he obtains his desire, these being verily ordained by Me (alone).
Translated: He worships that deity with the devotion and receives from it the desired enjoyments which I have ordained.

Original: 7.23 Verily the reward (fruit) that accrues to those men of small intelligence is finite. The worshippers of the gods go to them, but My devotees come to Me.
Translated: But the fruit of those little wise men is destructive. The gods of the gods come to the gods and my devotees come to me.

Original: 7.24 The foolish think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having manifestation, knowing not My higher, immutable and most excellent nature.
Translated: The wise men do not know my supreme (best) supreme feeling, but regard me as manifest.

Original: 7.25 I am not manifest to all (as I am) veiled by the Yoga-Maya. This deluded world does not know Me, the unborn and imperishable.
Translated: I am not visible to everyone in my Yoga. This enchanted people (mankind) does not know me as unborn, immortal.

Original: 7.26 I know, O Arjuna, the beings of the past, the present and the future, but no one knows Me.
Translated: I know only the past and the present and the future, O Arjuna, but no man knows me.

Original: 7.27 By the delusion of the pairs of opposites arising from desire and aversion, O Bharata, all beings are subject to delusion at birth, O Parantapa.
Translated: 7. 27 - LRB - Heavenly India - RRB - Conflicts of will and hatred give rise to love only during the last evolutionary period.

Original: 7.28 But those men of virtuous deeds whose sins have come to an end, and who are freed from the delusion of the pairs of opposites, worship Me, steadfast in their vows.
Translated: 7.28. But the sins of the virtuous men who have been destroyed, those who are free from conflict and who are steadfast, exhort me.

Original: 7.29 Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realise in full ï1thatï1 Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self and all action.
Translated: Those who, by joining me, try to get rid of the roots and death know the Brahman, the whole spirituality and the whole action.

Original: 7.30 Those who know Me with the Adhibhuta (pertaining to the elements), Adhidaiva (pertaining to the gods) and the Adhiyajna (pertaining to the sacrifice) know Me even at the time of death, steadfast in mind.
Translated: 7.30. The men who know me, including the supreme and the supernatural and the superconscious, know me even in the last days.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Arjuna said, 'O Purushaottam! What is Brahman, what is spirituality, and what is karma, and what is called the supernatural name, and what is called the supernatural name,

Original: 8.2 Who and how is Adhiyajna here in this body, O destroyer of Madhu (Krishna)? And how at the time of death, art Thou to be known by the self-controlled?
Translated: 8. 2 And, honey, who is the Adjuster here? And how is he in this body? And how do you know at the end of the time by the men who are devoutly conscious?

Original: 8.3 The Blessed Lord said  Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme; Its essential nature is called Self-knowledge; the offering (to the gods) which causes existence and manifestation of beings and which also sustains them is called action.
Translated: 8. 3. Sri Bhagwan said - The supreme literal (inanimate) element is Brahman; the nature (its own nature) is called spirituality; the devil 's emotions generated by the devil' s devil (knowledge, motive force) is known as karma.

Original: 8.4 Adhibhuta (knowledge of the elements) pertains to My perishable Nature and the Purusha or the Soul is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied (men).
Translated: 8. 4 Arjuna, the best of the dwellers of the earth, the deity is supreme and the man supreme; in this body I am the supreme.

Original: 8.5 And whosoever, leaving the body, goes forth remembering Me alone, at the time of death, he attains My Being: there is no doubt about this.
Translated: And there is no doubt that whosoever leaves the body, remembering Me only in the end, receives My form.

Original: 8.6 Whosoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), because of his constant thought of that being.
Translated: In the end, whatever emotions the soul renounces in remembrance, it always receives as a result of the thought of that emotion.

Original: 8.7 Therefore at all times remember Me only and fight. With mind and intellect fixed (or absorbed) in Me, thou shalt doubtessly come to Me alone.
Translated: Therefore, remember Me continually all the time, and fight, minded and wise, and you shall surely be given to Me.

Original: 8.8 With the mind not moving towards any other thing, made steadfast by the method of habitual meditation, and constantly meditating, one goes to the Supreme Person, the Resplendent, O Arjuna.
Translated: 8. 8, 8 - LRB - 'Heath' - RRB - The Yoga of Practice brings to the Supreme Divine Purusha the constant consciousness from the unknown consciousness.

Original: 8.9 Whosoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler (of the whole world), minuter than an atom, the supporter of all, of inconceivable form, effulgent like the sun and beyond the darkness of ignorance.
Translated: Who remembers the Purusha, the all - knowing, the ancient (Puran), the initiator of all, even the subtlest of all, the thread of all, the form of consciousness, the form of light like the sun, and the element beyond darkness.

Original: 8.10 At the time of death, with unshaken mind, endowed with devotio, by the power of Yoga, fixing the whole life-breath in the middle of the two eyrows, he reaches that resplendent Supreme Person.
Translated: 8.10. In the last time, he gets the supreme divine soul by placing the life in the midst of the womb with the Yoga force, devoting himself to the unshakable mind.

Original: 8.11 That which is declared Imperishable by those who know the Vedas, that which the self-controlled (ascetics or Sannyasins) and passion-free enter, that desiring which celibacy is practised  that goal I will declare to thee in brief.
Translated: The scholars who know the Veda, who call themselves the 'letters', the lustless, diligent man who enters, who by his will follows the Brahmacharya - I will briefly tell you about that term.

Original: 8.12 Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart and fixed the life-breath in the head, engaged in the practice of concentration.
Translated: 8.1.2. In Yoga, all the doors of the senses were restrained, the mind fixed in the heart, and the life set in the head.

Original: 8.13 Uttering the one-syllabled Om  the Brahman  and remembering Me, he who departs, leaving the body, attains to the Supreme Goal.
Translated: The man who pronounces this one letter Brahma and renounces the body in remembrance of me receives the supreme speed.

Original: 8.14 I am easily attainable by that ever-steadfast Yogi who constantly and daily remembers Me (for a long time), not thinking of anything else (with a single mind or one-pointed mind), O Partha (Arjuna).
Translated: I am readily available to the eternal yogi who remembers me, O Path!

Original:
8.15 Having attained Me these great souls do not again take birth (here) which is the place of pain 
and is non-eternal: they have reached the highest perfection (liberation).
Translated: 8.15. The Mahatma who receives the supreme perfection does not receive the rhythmic rebirth of unreal sorrow by receiving me.

Original: 8.16 (All) the worlds including the world of Brahma are subject to return again, O Arjuna; but he who reaches Me, O son of Kunti, has no rirth.
Translated: 8. 16. “O Arjuna, all people up to the Brahman world are reborn, but, oh my God, I will not be reborn when I am received. ”

Original: 8.17 Those people who know the day of Brahma which is of a duration of a thousand Yugas (ages) and the night which is also of a thousand Yugas duration, they know day and night.
Translated: Those who know the period of a day of Brahman, which is a thousand years, and a night of a thousand years, are men who know the day and the night.

Original: 8.18 From the Unmanifested all the manifested (worlds) proceed at the coming of the 'day'; at the coming of the 'night' they dissolve verily into ï1thatï1 alone which is called the Unmanifested.
Translated: 8.18. On the rise of the day (of Brahman), the manifest emerges from the invisible; and on the rise of the night (of Brahman) it is merged into the same invisible.

Original: 8.19 This same multitude of beings, being born again and again, is dissolved, helplessly, O Arjuna (into the Unmanifested) at the coming of the night and comes forth at the coming of the day.
Translated: 8.19. He is the ghost who reappears and reappears as a leon. Awash was (the ghost story) reveals the leon at the dawn of the night and the dawn of the day.

Original: 8.20 But verily there exists, higher than this Unmanifested, another unmanifested Eternal, which is not destroyed when all beings are destroyed.
Translated: But beyond the unexpressed, the other eternal unexpressed emotion does not perish even when all beings perish.

Original: 8.21 What is called the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That they say is the highest goal. They who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My highest abode (place or state).
Translated: What is called the unexpressed letter is the supreme momentum, which, when it is received, does not return, it is my supreme home.

Original: 8.22 That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded.
Translated: 8.22. O Path! The Supreme Being, within whom are all the devils and from whom this wholeness is encompassed, can be obtained only by exclusive devotion.

Original: 8.23 Now I will tell thee, O chief of Bharatas, the times departing at which the Yogis will return or not return.
Translated: I will tell you, O Bharatshreshtha, the time when the yogis who have abandoned their bodies receive rebirth and (or) rebirth.

Original: 8.24 Fire, light daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the northern path of the sun (the northern solstice)  departing then (by these) men who know Brahman go to Brahman.
Translated: The Brahman saints who, after their death, go through the six - month path of fire, light, day, moon and sunset, get to Brahman.

Original: 8.25 Attaining to the lunar light by smoke, night time, the dark fortnight also, the six months of the southern path of the sun (the southern solstice), the Yogi returns.
Translated: 8.25. The yogi returns to the moon by receiving the light of the moon through the six - month path of the comet, night, the moon side and the southern moon.

Original: 8.26 The bright and the dark paths of the world are verily thought to be eternal; by the one (the bright path) a man goes not to return and by the other (the dark path) he returns.
Translated: These two kinds of Shukla and Krishna paths of the world are considered to be eternal. One of them (Shukla) brings about (the lasting) rebirth and the other (Krishna) brings about a rebirth.

Original: 8.27 Knowing these paths, O Arjuna, no Yogi is deluded; therefore at all times be steadfast in Yoga.
Translated: No Yogi who knows these two paths is enchanted. Therefore, Arjuna, become Yogic in time.

Original: 8.28 Whatever fruit of merit is declared (in the scriptures) to accrue from (the study of) the Vedas, (the performance of) sacrifices, (the practice of) austerities, and gifts  beyond all this goes the Yogi, having known this; and he attains to the Supreme Primeval (first or ancient) Abode.
Translated: The yogi man, knowing all this (the principles of the two ways), goes beyond what is called the virtuous fruit of teaching, sacrifice, penance and charity, and attains the highest place.

Original: 9.1 The Blessed Lord said  I shall now declare to thee who does not cavil, the greatest secret, the knowledge combined with experience (Self-realisation). Having known this thou shalt be free evil.
Translated: 9. 1. Sri Bhagwan said - For you who are blind, I will say this supreme knowledge with science, which you will be freed from evil.

Original: 9.2 This is the kingl science, the kingly secret, the supreme purifier, realisable by direct intuitional knowledge, according to righteousness, very easy to perform and imperishable.
Translated: This knowledge is Rajivya (the king of the sciences) and Rajguha (the king of all the ghosts, i. e. the mystics) and is holy, good, direct, knowledgeable and religious, and easy to do and inexpensive.

Original: 9.3 Those who have no faith in this Dharma (knowledge of the Self), O Parantapa (Arjuna), return to the path of this world of death without attaining Me.
Translated: 9. 3. In this religion, the faithless men live in the world of death, not receiving me.

Original: 9.4 All this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist in Me, but I do not dwell in them.
Translated: This whole world is encompassed by the invisible nature of me (the spirit); all the devils are in me, but I am not in them.

Original: 9.5 Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold My divine Yoga, supporting all beings, but not dwelling in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.
Translated: And not only is the devil in me; see my divine Yoga that my soul which holds the devils and produces the devils is not in those devils.

Original: 9.6 As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, rests always in the ether, even so, know thou that all beings rest in Me.
Translated: As the great air that circulates all over is always in the sky, so is the whole world in me, as you know.

Original: 9.7 All beings, O Arjuna, go into My Nature at the end of a Kalpa; I send them forth again at the beginning of (the next) Kalpa.
Translated: 9. 7. O God! At the end of the dream all the ghosts come to My nature; and at the beginning of the dream I create them again.

Original: 9.8 Animating My Nature, I again and again send forth all this multitude of beings, helpless by the force of the Nature.
Translated: 9. 8. I re - create this whole devil community, subdued by nature (i. e. by giving it consciousness), subdued by nature.

Original: 9.9 These acts do not bind Me, O Arjuna, sitting like one indifferent, unattached to those acts.
Translated: They do not bind me - LRB - the soul - RRB - who is indifferent and depressed in these works.

Original: 9.10 Under Me as supervisor, Nature produces the moving and the unmoving; because of this, O Arjuna, the world revolves.
Translated: 9. 10. < s > Because of my Chairman (i. e. under my Chairmanship), Nature creates a world of creatures; hence the world revolves.

Original: 9.11 Fools disregard Me, clad in human form, not knowing My higher Being as the great Lord of (all) beings.
Translated: The great God form of all the devils does not know my supreme feeling and the foolish people, the human beings, disrespect my God.

Original: 9.12 Of vain hopes, of vain actions, of vain knowledge and senseless, they verily are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings.
Translated: 9. 12. The unthinking people of old hope, old work and old knowledge possess the charming nature of the demons and the devils.

Original: 9.13 But the great souls, O Arjuna, partaking of My divine nature, worship Me with a single mind (with the mind devoted to nothing else), knowing Me as the imperishable source of beings.
Translated: But the Mahatma, who is dependent on the divine nature, glorifies me, knowing all the devils as primitive and inexhaustible, full of unity.

Original: 9.14 Always glorifying Me, striving,firm in vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me with devotion always steadfast.
Translated: 9.14. The hardworking, hardworking men greet me constantly, worship me devoutly and eternally.

Original: 9.15 Others also sacrificing with the wisdom-sacrifice worship Me, the All-faced, as one, as distinct, and as manifold.
Translated: Some worship me in a united way by worshipping me with knowledge, some worship me in a separate way, some worship me in many ways in a universal form.

Original: 9.16 I am the Kratu; I am the Yajna; I am the offering (food) to the manes; I am the medicinal herbs and all the plants; I am the Mantra; I am also the Ghee or the melted butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation.
Translated: 9. 16. I am Krishna; I am Yajna; I am Sudha and Medicine; I am Mantra, I am Ghai, I am Agni and I am Hutan, or the Hawan Karma.

Original:
9.17 I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions and the 
grandfather; the (one) thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik-, the Sama-and the Yajur-Vedas.
Translated: 9. 17. I am the father, mother, father - in - law and father - in - law of this world. I am the instrument, the holy, the ovar, the Rig Veda, the Sama Veda and the Yajur Veda.

Original: 9.18 I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house and the seed which is imperishable.
Translated: 9.18. I am also the mover, the bearer of burdens, the Lord, the witness, the dweller, the shelter and the friend, and the source, the cause of death and the place of repose, and the cause of loss.

Original: 9.19 (As the sun) I give heat; I withhold and send forth the rain; I am immortality and also death, existence and non-existence, O Arjuna.
Translated: 9. 19. < s > O Arjuna, I am the Hearer, I am the Disposer and the Producer of the rain. I am the nectar, the death, the being and the spirit.

Original: 9.20 The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me by sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy in heavn the divine pleasures of the gods.
Translated: 9.20. The saints of the three Vedas (the practitioners of the aforementioned sacraments), the people who drink and are purified from sins desire to receive heaven by worshipping me through sacrifices; they receive the rainbow as the fruit of their virtues and enjoy the divine gods in heaven.

Original: 9.21 They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the ï1threeï1 (Vedas) and desiring (objects of) desires, they attain to the state of going and returning.
Translated: By experiencing that vast heavenly world, when they are deprived of virtue, they arrive at the world of death. Thus, the males who are sheltered by the action mentioned in the three Vedas and who desire to enjoy it, arrive at the gateway.

Original: 9.22 For those men who worship Me alone, thinking of no other, for those ever-united, I secure what is not already possessed and preserve what they already possess.
Translated: In my unique thought, I join the eternal men whom the devotees worship with me.

Original: 9.23 Even those devotees who, endowed with faith, worship other gods, worship Me alone, O Arjuna, b the wrong method.
Translated: The devotees who worship other gods with devotion also worship Me inviolably.

Original: 9.24 (For) I alone am the enjoyer and also the Lord of all sacrifices; but they do not know Me in essence (in reality), and hence they fall (return to this mortal world).
Translated: Since I am the feeder and master of all sacrifices, but they do not know me in principle, they fall, that is to say, they reach the world.

Original: 9.25 The worshippers of the gods go to them; to the manes go the ancestor-worshippers; to the deities who preside over the elements go their worshippers; but My devotees come to Me.
Translated: 9.25. The worshippers of the gods come to the gods, the father worshippers come to the fathers, the devils who inhabit the devils come to the devils, and the devotees who worship me come to me.

Original: 9.26 Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit or a little water  that, so offered devotedly by the pure-minded, I accept.
Translated: 9.26. Whoever devotes letters, flowers, fruits, water, etc. to me in devotion, the devotee of the pure mind whom he devotes in devotion - LRB - letters, flowers - RRB - I enjoy, i. e. accept.

Original: 9.27 Whatever thou doest, whatever thou eatest, whatever thou offerest in sacrifice, whatever thou givest, whatever thou practisest as austerity, O Arjuna, do it as an offering unto Me.
Translated: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you burn, whatever you give, whatever you meditate on, all these things give to me.

Original: 9.28 Thus shalt thou be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil fruits; with the mind steadfast in the Yoga of renunciation, and liberated, thou shalt come unto Me.
Translated: In this way you will be freed from the bonds of karma as a result of good and evil; and you will be freed from Me, having become conscious of the Sanyasi Yoga.

Original: 9.29 The same am I to all beings; to Me there is none hateful or dear; but those who worship Me with devotion are in Me and I am also in them.
Translated: I am equal to all the devils; none hates me or loves me; but those who worship me are within me and I am among them.

Original: 9.30 Even if the most sinful worships Me, with devotion to none else, he too should indeed by regarded as righteous for he has rightly resolved.
Translated: 9. 30. If even the most ruthless man devotes himself to me as a devotee, he is only worthy of being regarded as a saint, for he is truthful and determined.

Original: 9.31 Soon he becomes righteous and attains to eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.
Translated: He soon becomes a religious soul and receives eternal peace. You certainly know the truth that my devotee never perishes.

Original: 9.32 For, taking refuge in Me, they also who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth  women, Vaisyas as well as Sudras  attain the Supreme Goal.
Translated: 9.32. O pilgrims, women, Vaishyas and Shudras, whoever is a sinner, they too have recourse to Me and come to the supreme speed.

Original: 9.33 How much more (easily) then the hold Brahmins and devoted royal saints (attain the goal); having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.
Translated: 9. 33. What is it to say, then, that the virtuous Brahmins and the Rajrshi devotees (have reached the supreme speed); (so) by reaching this uncertain and unhappy people (now) worship Me with devotion.

Original: 9.34 Fix thy mind on Me; by devoted to Me; sacrifice unto Me; bow down to Me; having thus united thy whole self to Me, taking Me as the supreme goal, thou shalt come unto Me.
Translated: Be steadfast in me; be devotees and worshippers of me; greet me; thus you will come to me, having taken the Spirit from me, as I am the ultimate goal.

Original: 10.1 The Blessed Lord said  Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to thee who who art beloved, for thy welfare.
Translated: Shri Bhagwan said, "O Mahabharata, again, listen to my supreme words, which I will say with the will of good for the one who loves you most.

Original: 10.2 Neither the hosts of the gods nor the great sages know My origin; for in every way I am the source of all the gods and the great sages.
Translated: 10. 2. I am not known by the gods or by the lords, for I am also the father of all kinds of gods and lords.

Original: 10.3 He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds, he, among mortals, is undeluded and he is liberated from all sins.
Translated: 10. 3. Who knows me as the Almighty, the Invisible and the Great God of the worlds, such an enchanted (knowing) man in mankind is free from all sins.

Original: 10.4 Intellect, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, calmness, happiness, pain, existence or birth, non-existence or death, fear and also fearlessness.
Translated: 10.4. Reason, knowledge, lack of affection, forgiveness, truth, suppression (sensory restraint), shame (mind: restraint), happiness, suffering, birth and death, fear and fear.

Original: 10.5 Non-injury, eanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame, ill-fame  (these) different kinds of alities of beings arise from Me alone.
Translated: 10. 5 I am the embodiment of the various emotions of these beings: non - violence, equality, contentment, penance, charity, success and failure.

Original: 10.6 The seven great sages, the ancient four and also the Manus, possessed of powers like Me (on account of their minds being fixed on Me), were born of (My) mind; from them are these creatures born in this world.
Translated: The seven Maharshijans, the four of the ancients (Sankadi) and the fourteen Manus, are born of my will of influence, of which they are subjects in the world.

Original: 10.7 He who in truth knows these manifold manifestations of My Being and (this) Yoga-power of Mine becomes established in the unshakable Yoga; there is no doubt about it.
Translated: There is no doubt that the man who knows this myth and Yoga from the principle is possessed by the uncompromising Yoga (i. e. the Yoga of Immovable Attention).

Original: 10.8 I am the source of all; from Me everything evolves; understanding thus, the wise, endowed with meditation, worship Me.
Translated: 10. 8 I am the place of all; I am the source of all development, so the Buddhists, with a sense of devotion, mourn for me.

Original: 10.9 With their mind and their life wholly absorbed in Me, enlightening each other and ever speaking of Me, they are satisfied and delighted.
Translated: The devotees who are the stabilizers of the psyche in me and the devotees of the souls in me are always satisfied and rejoicing in their mutual perception of me, in their statements about me.

Original: 10.10 To them who are ever steadfast, worshipping Me with love, I give the Yoga of discrimination by which they come to Me.
Translated: 10. 10. I give to those devotees who are always attached to me and who love to recite my hymns, the 'Enlightenment' which they receive from me.

Original: 10.11 Out of mere compassion for them, I, dwelling within their Self, destroy the darkness born of ignorance by the luminous lamp of knowledge.
Translated: 10. 11. In order to grace them, I stand in their midst and destroy the darkness of ignorance by the lamp of luminous knowledge.

Original: 10.12 Arjuna said  Thou art the Supreme Brahman, the supreme abode (or the supreme light), the supreme purifier, eternal, divine Person, the primeval God, unborn andn omnipresent.
Translated: Arjuna said: You are the supreme Brahman, the supreme dharma and the supreme holy; the eternal divine man, the gods and goddesses, are unborn and omnipresent.

Original: 10.13 All the sages have thus declared Thee, as also the divine sage Narada; so also Asita, Devala and Vyasa; and now Thou Thyself sayest so to me.
Translated: This is what all the sages call you; the same is what Dewarri Narada, Asit, Deval Rishi and Vyas and yourself call me.

Original: 10.14 I believe all this that Thou sayest to me to be true, O Krishna; verily, O blessed Lord! neither the gods nor the demons know Thy manifestation (origin).
Translated: Whatever you say to me, I believe to be the truth. God, you are neither a deity nor a devil.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: 10. 15 - O Purushaottam! O devil spirit! O devil spirit! O God of the gods! O Lord of the world! You know yourselves.

Original: 10.16 Thou shouldst indeed tell, without reserve, of Thy divine glories by which Thou existest, pervading all these worlds. (None else can do so.)
Translated: 10. 16. You are the one who is inexhaustibly capable of describing the divine revelations by which you have pervaded all these worlds.

Original:
10.17 How shall I, ever meditating, know Thee, O Yogin? In what aspects or things, O blessed 
Lord, art Thou to be thought of by me?
Translated: 10. 17. I know how I am constantly thinking, O God, and in what emotions You are able to think by me.

Original: 10.18 Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of Thy Yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of Thy life-giving and nectar-like speech.
Translated: 10. 18. < s > Dear Janaran, repeat your Yoga power and insight, for I am not satisfied when I hear your immortal words.

Original: 10.19 The Blessed Lord said  Very well! Now I will declare to thee My divine glories in their prominence, O Arjuna; there is no end to their detailed description.
Translated: Sri Bhagwan said, “Now I will tell you my divine revelations first and foremost. O Kurukshreshtha, my extension is not the end. ”

Original: 10.20 I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle and also the end of all beings.
Translated: 10. 20. I am the soul of all in the heart of all devils, and I am the beginning, the middle and the end of all devils.

Original: 10.21 Among the (twelve) Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, the radiant sun; I am Marichi among the (seven or forty-nine) Maruts; among stars the moon am I.
Translated: 10. 21. I am Vishnu among the Aditis and the Absolute Sun among the Jyotis; I am Marichi among the Merats and the Shashi among the stars.

Original: 10.22 Among the Vedas I am the Sama-Veda; I am Vasava among the gods; among the senses I am the mind; and I am intelligence among living beings.
Translated: 10. 22. I am the Samveda in the Vedas, the Vasava in the gods, the mind in the senses and the consciousness in the spirits.

Original: 10.23 And, among the Rudras I am Sankara; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, the Lord of wealth (Kubera); among the Vasus I am Pavaka (fire); and among the (seven) mountains I am the Meru.
Translated: 10. 23. I am Sankara in the Rudras and Dhanpati Kuber in the Rakshas and Yaks; I am Agni in the Vasu and Meru in the mountains of the Sikhara.

Original:
10.24 And, among the household priests (of kings), O Arjuna, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati; among the army generals I am Skana; among lakes I am the ocean.
'
Translated: 10. 24. O pilgrims, know me as Jupiter among the priests; I am the shield in the captains and the sea in the tanks.

Original: 10.25 Among the great sages I am Bhrigu; among words I am the one syllable (Om); among sacrifices I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; among the immovable things I am the Himalayas.
Translated: 10. 25 - I am the one - letter scribe in beetles and words in the months. I am the Japatian in the sacrifices and the Himalayan in the statues.

Original: 10.26 Among all the trees ( I am) the Peepul; among the divine sages, I am Narada; among Gandharvas, Chitraratha; among the perfected, the sage Kapila.
Translated: 10. 26. I am Ashwattha in all the trees and Narada in the Devasharis; I am Chitrarath in the Gandharvas and Kapil Muni in the Siddhas.

Original: 10.27 Know Me as Ucchaisravas born of nectar, among horses; among lordly elephants (I am) the Airavata; and, among men, the king.
Translated: 10. 27. < s > Know Me, the Highest Shepherd born of Amrit in the sheep, Arawat in the elephants, and the King in the people.

Original: 10.28 Among weapons I am the thunderbolt; among cows I am the wish-fulfilling cow called Kamadhenu; I am the progenitor, the god of love; among serpents I am Vasuki.
Translated: 10. 28. I am the bearer of weapons, the bearer of dragons, the bearer of creatures and the bearer of serpents.

Original: 10.29 I am Ananta among the Nagas; I am Varuna among water-deities; Aryaman among the Manes I am; I am Yama among the governors.
Translated: 10. 29. I am the Infinite in the serpents and the Varuna in the water gods; I am Arya in the fathers and Yam in the rulers.

Original: 10.30 And, I am Prahlada among the demons, among the reckoners I am time; among beasts I am the lion, and Vainateya (Garuda) among birds.
Translated: 10. 30. I am among the gods, among the praised and counted, I am among the lions, among the lion (Migendra) and among the birds.

Original: 10.31 Among the purifiers (or the speeders) I am the wind; Rama among the warriors am I; among the fishes I am the shark; among the streams I am the Ganga.
Translated: 10. 31. I am the air in the purifiers and the Rama in the armor bearers; and in the fish I am the crocodile and in the rivers I am the Ganges.

Original: 10.32 Among creations I am the beginning, the middle and also the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists.
Translated: 10. 32. O Arjuna, I am the beginning, the end and the middle of creations, I am the spirituality of the sciences and I am the cause of controversy.

Original:
10.33 Among the letters of the alphabets, the letter 'A' I am and the dual among the compounds. I am verily the inexhaustible or everlasting time; I am the dispenser (of the fruits of actions) having 
faces in all directions.
Translated: 10. 33. I am a weakness in the letters (alphabet) and a conflict in the syllables (namely the syllables); I am an invincible age and a world - oriented (violent) philosopher.

Original: 10.34 And I am the all-devouring Death, and the prosperity of those who are to be prosperous; among the feminine alities (I am) fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness and forgiveness.
Translated: 10.34. I am the cause of universal death and the birth of those who will be; in women I am the virtue, the honour, the speech, the memory, the grace, the grace and the forgiveness.

Original: 10.35 Among the hymns also I am the Brihatsaman; among metres Gayatri am I; among the montsh I am the Margasirsha; among the seasons (I am) the flowery season.
Translated: 10. 35. I am the Great Sam in the Sams (Gya Mantras) and the Gayatri metre in the verses; I am the Mahashira (part of the month of December) in the months and the Vaishna in the seasons.

Original: 10.36 I am the gambling of the fraudulent; I am the splendour of the splendid; I am victory; I am determination (of those who are determined); I am the goodness of the good.
Translated: 10. 36. I am wicked in the deceivers and strong in the spirits, I am victorious; I am entrepreneur and I am the spirit of the sacred men.

Original: 10.37 Among the Vrishnis I am Vaasudeva; among the Pandavas I am Arjuna; among the sages I am Vyasa; among the Poets I am Usanas, the poet.
Translated: 10. 37. I am Vasudeva in the elders and Dhanjay in the Pandavas, I am Vis in the sages and Ushana poet in the poets.

Original: 10.38 Of those who punish, I am the sceptre; among those who seek victory, I am statesmanship; and also among secrets, I am silence; knowledge among knowers I am.
Translated: 10. 38. I am the punishment of the oppressors and the policy of the victorious; I am the silence of the sinners and the knowledge of the wise.

Original: 10.39 And whatever is the seed of all beings, that also am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, whether moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.
Translated: 10. 39. “O Arjuna, who is the seed of the origin of all devils, I am in him too, for there is no flesh and bloodless devil without me. ”

Original: 10.40 There is no end to My divine gloreis, O Arjuna, but this is a brief statement by Me of the particulars of My divine glories.
Translated: 10. 40. O Supreme! My divine revelations are not the end; this expansion of my revelations I have said to a country, in short.

Original: 10.41 Whatever being there is glorious, prosperous or powerful, that know thou to be a manifestation of a part of My splendour.
Translated: 10. 41. Know that whatever is enlightened, enlightened, or powerful (or creature) is born of a part of My power.

Original: 10.42 But, of what avail to thee is the knowledge of all these details, O Arjuna? I exist, supporting this whole world by one part of Myself.
Translated: 10. 42 Or, O Arjun, what is your purpose in knowing so much? I stand with the whole world as a part of myself.

Original: 11.1 Arjuna said  By this word (explanation) of the highest secret concerning the Self which Thou hast spoken, for the sake of blessing me, my delusion is gone.
Translated: Arjun said - I have lost my affection for the supreme secret, spiritual vow (prayer) which you have spoken to me for grace.

Original: 11.2 The origin and the destruction of beings verily have been heard by me in detail from Thee, O lotus-eyed Lord, and also Thy inexhaustible greatness.
Translated: I have heard you extensively about the origin and destruction of the devils and also about your inexhaustible spirituality.

Original: 11.3 (Now) O Supreme Lord, as Thou hast thus described Thyself, O Supreme Person, I wish to see Thy divine form.
Translated: This is exactly what you say of yourself, O God. (But) O Purushaottam, I want to see your divine form.

Original: 11.4 If Thou, O Lord, thinkest it possible for me to see it, do Thou, then, O Lord of the Yogins, show me Thy imperishable Self.
Translated: If you believe that it is possible for me to see your form, then, O Yogeshwar, see your inexhaustible form.

Original: 11.5 The Blessed Lord said  Behold, O Arjuna, forms of Mine, by the hundreds and thousands, of different sorts, divine, and of various colours and shapes.
Translated: 11. 5 Sri Bhagwan said, "O Parth, look at my hundreds and thousands of various forms, and the divine forms of various colours and forms.

Original: 11.6 Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Asvins and also the Maruts; behold many wonders never seen before, O Arjuna.
Translated: 11.6. < s > O India, see the Adyths, Vasu, Rudras, Ashwinikumars, and Marudhanas, and many other wonders that have never been seen before.

Original: 11.7 Now behold, O Arjuna, in this, My body, the whole universe centred in one  including the moving and the unmoving  and whatever else thou desirest to see.
Translated: Today (now) see the whole world, including the birds in one place in my body, and see what else you want to see.

Original: 11.8 But thou art not able to behold Me with these thine own eyes; I give thee the divine eye; behold My lordly Yoga.
Translated: But you are not able to see me through these eyes of yours; therefore I give you a divine vision from which you can see my divine Yoga.

Original: 11.9 Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken, O king, the great Lord of Yoga, hari (Krishna), showed to Arjuna His supreme form as the Lord.
Translated: Sanjay said, "Hey Rajan, Mahayogaeshwar Hari once again showed Arjun the most divine form.

Original: 11.10 With numerous mouths and eyes, with numerous wonderful sights, with numerous divine ornaments, with numerous divine weapons uplifted (such a form He showed).
Translated: 11.10. He had many faces and eyes and many wonderful visions and many divine jewels and many divine weapons in his hands.

Original: 11.11 Wearing divine garlands (necklaces) and apparel, anointed with divine unguents, the all-wonderful, resplendent (Being) endless with faces on all sides.
Translated: In divine robes and garments and with divine scent, with all kinds of wonders, the infinite, the universal, the supreme God - LRB - whom Arjun saw - RRB -.

Original: 11.12 If the splendour of a thousand suns were to blaze out at once (simultaneously) in the sky, that would be the splendour of that mighty Being (great Soul).
Translated: 11. 12. The light that arises from the rise of a thousand suns together in the sky will be like the light of that (universal) God.

Original: 11.13 There, in the body of the God of gods, Arjuna then saw the whole universe resting in one, with its many groups.
Translated: 11. 13 - Panduputra Arjun saw the whole world divided in various ways at that time in one place in the body of Lord Krishna, the god of the gods.

Original: 11.14 Then, Arjuna, filled with wonder and with his hair standing on end, bowed down his head to the God and spoke with joined palms.
Translated: Afterwards, he was astonished to see the joyful Romans (who are experiencing a sensation) praising Dhanjay Arjuna Visvarupa Deva (with his devotion to the warrior) with his head joined by his hands.

Original: 11.15 Arjuna said  I see all the gods, O God, in Thy body, and (also) hosts of various classes of beings, Brahma, the Lord, seated on the lotus, all the sages and the celestial serpents.
Translated: Arjuna said, "My God, I see all the gods in your body and the communities of many special beings, and the Lord of the universe, Brahman, the sages and the divine serpents, who are on the throne.

Original: 11.16 I see Thee of boundless form on every side with many arms, stomachs, mouths and eyes: neither the end nor the middle nor also the beginning do I see, O Lord of the universe, O Cosmic Form.
Translated: I see you as multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted, multifaceted.

Original:
11.17 I see Thee with the diadem, the club and the discus, a mass of radiance shining 
everywhere, very hard to look at, blazing all round like burning fire and the sun, and immeasurable.
Translated: 11. 17. I see from all sides your crowned, crowned, cyclical, and from all sides luminous, bright, luminous, like the burning fire and the sun, a luminous, exceedingly difficult and immeasurable flame.

Original: 11.18 Thou art the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, worthy to be known. Thou art the great treasure-house of this universe; Thou art the imperishable protector of the eternal Dhrama; Thou art the Primal Person, I deem.
Translated: You are the Supreme Character; You are the supreme shelter of the world! You are the guardian of the eternal religion and you are the eternal soul, I believe.

Original: 11.19 I see Thee without beginning, middle or end, infinite in power, of endless arms, the sun and the moon being Thy eyes, the burning fire Thy mouth, heating the whole universe with Thy radiance.
Translated: 11.19. I see you beginning, endless and infinite, with infinite serenity, with infinite hands, with eyes like the moon and with a mouth like a flaming fire, and with my own light, spreading out this world.

Original: 11.20 This space between the earth and the heaven and all the arters are filled by Thee alone; having seen this, Thy wonderful and teriible form, the three worlds are trembling with fear, O great-souled Being.
Translated: The heavens and all directions between heaven and earth are inhabited by you alone, O Mahatma; the three peoples are being overwhelmed by your wonderful and violent form.

Original: 11.21 Verily, into Thee enter these hosts of gods; some extol Thee in fear with joined palms; saying 'may it be well', bands of great sages and perfected ones praise Thee with hymns complete.
Translated: These groups of all the gods are entering you, and many of them join hands in fear, praising you; the community of the Maharshi and the Siddhas praising you by the best (or all) sources, saying, 'Be blessed.'

Original: 11.22 The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the manes and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons and the perfected ones, are all looking at Thee, in great amazement.
Translated: 11.22. Rudraganas, Aditya, Vasu and Siddhaganas, Visvedev and two Ashwinikumars, Marudganas and Ushmpas, Gandharva, Yaksha, Asura and Siddhaganas - these are all the communities of wonder you see.

Original: 11.23 Having seen Thy immeasurable form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed, with many arms, thighs and feet, with many stomachs and fearful with many teeth  the worlds are terrified and so am I.
Translated: 11. 23. < s > O Mahabharaoh! Everyone is upset to see your great figure with many mouths and eyes, many ears, ears and feet, many ears and many crooked teeth, and so am I.

Original: 11.24 On seeing Thee (the Cosmic Form) touching the sky, shining in many colours, with mouths wide open, with large fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu.
Translated: I am terrified to see you touching the heavens in many luminous forms and having a flat face and luminous large eyes. I am not getting patience and peace.

Original: 11.25 Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth (blazing) like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four arters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.
Translated: 11. 25 - I cannot see the directions, nor can I find peace, when I see your flaming faces, like those of a fiery old man and a flaming fire; therefore, O Devas, O Jagannais, rejoice.

Original: 11.26 All the sons of Dhritarashtra, with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona and Karna, with the chief among our warriors.
Translated: And they enter you with the whole community of the sons of Dhritarashtra, the kings, Bhishma, Drona and Karna, and the chief warriors of our side.

Original: 11.27 Some hurriedly enter Thy mouths with their terrible teeth, fearful to behold. Some are found sticking in the gaps between the teeth with their heads crushed to powder.
Translated: 11. 27. < s > At high speed, your scalpels enter the horrific mouths of your teeth, and many of them appear to be stuck between your teeth, with one crushed head.

Original: 11.28 Verily, just as many torrents of rivers flow towards the ocean, even so these heroes in the world of men enter Thy flaming mouths.
Translated: As many rivers flow to the sea at speed, so these brave warriors of the world of man enter your burning mouths.

Original: 11.29 As moths hurriedly rush into a blazing fire for (their own) destruction, so also these creatures hurriedly rush into Thy mouths for (their own) destruction.
Translated: As flies enter the flaming fire for their destruction, so do they enter your mouths for their destruction.

Original: 11.30 Thou lickest up, devouring all the worlds on every side with Thy flaming mouths. Thy fierce rays, filling the whole world with radiance, are burning, O Vishnu!
Translated: 11. 30. You, Vishnu, greet all these peoples with your burning mouths, your fierce light filling the whole world with light.

Original: 11.31 Tell me, who Thou art, so fierce of form. Salutations to Thee, O God Supreme: have mercy. I desire to know Thee, the original Being. I know not indeed Thy working.
Translated: 11. 31. (Please) Say to me, Who are you of the extreme nature? Best of Gods! Greet you, please be happy. I want to know you of the extreme nature, because I do not understand your tendency (i. e. purpose).

Original: 11.32 The Blessed Lord said  I am the full-grown world-destroying Time, now engaged in destroying the worlds. Even without thee, none of the warriors arrayed in the hostile armies shall live.
Translated: Shri Bhagwan said - I am in the age of destruction of peoples. I am in the age of destruction of these peoples. Those who are warriors in the army of opponents will not live without you.

Original: 11.33 Therefore, stand up and obtain fame. Coner the enemies and enjoy the unrivalled kingdom. Verily by Me have they been already slain; be thou a mere instrument, O Arjuna.
Translated: Therefore, rise up and be victorious; conquer your enemies and enjoy a rich kingdom. All these have already been killed by me. O Savisachin, be thou only a helper.

Original: 11.34 Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna and other brave warriors  these are already slain by Me: do thou kill; be not distressed with fear; fight and thou shalt coner thy enemies in battle.
Translated: Kill the heroes Drone, Bhishma, Jayadrath, Karna and many others who have been killed by me; do not be afraid; fight; you will win the enemies in the battle.

Original: 11.35 Sanjaya said  Having heard that speech of Lord Krishna, Arjuna, with joined palms, trembling, prostrating himself, again addressed Krishna, in a choked voice, bowing down, overwhelmed with fear.
Translated: Sanjay said - Hearing this word of the Lord Keshav, Arjun the crown - bearer joined his hands, shook his hands, greeted him, and again feared and said to Srikrishna a lying word.

Original: 11.36 Arjuna said  It is meet, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Thy praise; demons fly in fear to all arters and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to Thee.
Translated: Arjuna said - It is worthy of your kirtana that the world rejoices greatly and receives affection. Fearful demons run in all directions and the community of all the theologians greet you.

Original: 11.37 And why should they not, O great Soul, bow to Thee Who art greater (than all else), the primal cause even of the Creator (Brahma), O Infinite Being, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe; Thou art the imperishable, the Being, the non-being and That which is the supreme (that which is beyond the Being and the non-being).
Translated: How can they not greet you, O Mahatma, the first and the best of the creators of Brahman? (For) O Infinite, O Devas, O Jagannavas, who is the Reality and the Literacy beyond these two, is You.

Original: 11.38 Thou art the primal God, the ancient Purusha, the supreme refuge of this universe, the knower, the knowable and the supreme Abode. By Thee is the universe pervaded, O Being of infinite forms.
Translated: You are the Adidev and Purana (Satan) Man. You are the supreme shelter, the Knower, the Knower, the (knowable) and the Supreme Being of this world. You alone are the eternal embodiment of this world.

Original: 11.39 Thou art Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the moon, the Creator, and the great-grandfather. Salutations, salutations unto Thee, a thousand times, and again salutations, salutations unto Thee.
Translated: You are the air, the heavens, the fire, the sun, the moon, the goddess (Bharama) and the father - in - law (because of the Brahman); to you greetings a thousand times, greetings again, greetings again.

Original: 11.40 Salutations to Thee, in front and behind! Salutations to Thee on every side! O All!! Thou infinite in power and prowess, pervadest all; wherefore Thou art all.
Translated: 11. 40. “O God of infinite mercy! Greetings to you from the front and the back, O Almighty! Greetings to you from all sides. You are immensely brave and have encompassed you all, and from this you are all. ”

Original: 11.41 Whatever I have presumptuously said from carelessness or love, addressing Thee as O Krishna! O Yadava! O Friend! regarding Thee merely as a friend, unknowing of this, Thy greatness.
Translated: 11. 41. Dear God, not knowing this glory of yours as a Sakha, and not knowing this glory of yours as a Sakha, I have spoken to you with praise or love, "O Krishna, O Yadav, O Sakha!"

Original: 11.42 In whatever way I may have insulted Thee for the sake of fun, while at play, reposing, sitting or at meals, when alone (with Thee), O Krishna, or in company  that I implore Thee, immeasurable one, to forgive.
Translated: And, O Achyut, whom you have been humiliated by me in Bihar, in bed, sitting and eating alone or even in the presence of others for laughter, I condemn you in an unforgivable manner.

Original: 11.43 Thou art the Father of this world, moving and unmoving. Thou art to be adored by this world, Thou, the greatest Guru; (for) none there exists who is eal to Thee; how then could there be another superior to Thee in the three worlds, O Being of unealled power?
Translated: You are the father, the most revered and the best guru of this world. O God of eternal influence! There is none like you in all three worlds, so how could it be better than you?

Original:
11.44 Therefore, bowing down, prostrating my body, I crave Thy forgiveness, O adorable Lord. As a father forgives his son, a friend his (dear) friend, a lover his beloved, even so shouldst Thou 
forgive me, O God.
Translated: Therefore, O God, I pray that you, worthy of praise, may rejoice in the presence of God through the body. O God, forgive my sins just as the Father forgives the Son, the Friend forgives the Friend, and the Beloved forgives the Father.

Original: 11.45 I am delighted, having seen what has never been seen before; and yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that (previous) form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe.
Translated: 11. 45. I am delighted to see you in this unprecedented form, and my mind is overwhelmed with fear. Therefore, O God, show me the same epoch. O Devas, O Jagannais, please.

Original: 11.46 I desire to see Thee as before, crowned, bearing a mace, with the discus in hand, in Thy former form only, having four arms, O thousand-armed, Cosmic Form (Being).
Translated: I would like to see you, likewise, with crowns, shields and wheels in your hands. < s > O Visvaमूर्तe! O Thousand Years! Be of that quadrilateral shape.

Original: 11.47 The Blessed Lord said  O Arjuna, this Cosmic Form has graciously been shown to thee by Me by My own Yogic power; full of splendour, primeval, and infinite, this Cosmic Form of Mine has never been seen before by anyone other than thyself.
Translated: 11. 47. I am glad to see you, Arjuna, that through the power of my Yoga I have shown you this supreme, all and infinite universe which no one has seen before you.

Original: 11.48 Neither by the study of the Vedas and sacrifices, nor by gifts nor by rituals nor by severe austerities can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than thyself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna).
Translated: I cannot be seen in this form by anyone else in this human world except you, O Kuruphira, neither by meditation, nor by sacrifice, nor by charity, nor by (religious) acts, nor by violent penances.

Original: 11.49 Be not afraid, nor bewildered on seeing such a teriible form of Mine as this; with thy fear dispelled and with a gladdened heart, now behold again this former form of Mine.
Translated: Thus, you will not be despondent and foolish when you see me in this grave form. Be fearless and rejoice and see me again in the same form.

Original: 11.50 Sanjaya said  Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form and the great Soul (Krishna), assuming His gentle form, consoled him (Arjuna) who was terrified.
Translated: Sanjay said - Lord Vasudeva once again showed his (former) form to Arjuna, and then, the gentle form of Mahatma Krishna assured this fearful Arjuna.

Original: 11.51 Arjuna said  Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and am restored to my own nature.
Translated: Arjun said, "Dear Janaran, I have come to my own nature, calmed by your gentle human form.

Original: 11.52 The Blessed Lord said  Very hard indeed it is to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen. Even the gods are ever longing to behold it.
Translated: Shri Bhagwan said - It is very rare for me to see this form which you have seen. The gods too are always eager to see this form.

Original: 11.53 Neither by the Vedas nor by austerity, nor by gift, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as thou hast seen Me (so easily).
Translated: I can be seen as you have seen me, neither by the Vedas, nor by the penance, nor by the gift, nor by the sacrifice.

Original: 11.54 But by single-minded devotion can I, of this Form, be known and seen in reality and also entered into, O Arjuna.
Translated: But, O supreme Arjuna, by exclusive devotion I am, in principle, able to 'know', 'see' and 'enter' (to be received in one spirit).

Original: 11.55 He who does all actions for Me, who looks upon Me as the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who bears enmity towards no creature, he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
Translated: He who works for me, He who regards me as the ultimate goal, He who is my devotee, He who is devout, He who is devout to the devil, He who is devout to the only devil, He comes to me.

Original: 12.1 Arjuna said  Those devotees who, ever steadfast, thus worship Thee and those also who worship the imperishable and the unmanifested  which of them are better versed in Yoga?
Translated: Arjuna said - Who is the best yogi among the devotees who worship you in this manner (as aforesaid) constantly and who worship the literal and the impersonal?

Original: 12.2 The Blessed Lord said  Those who, fixing their mind on Me, worship Me, ever steadfast and endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga in My opinion.
Translated: Shri Bhagwan said - The devotees who worship me with the utmost devotion are, in my opinion, the best, that is to say, the best.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Swami Tejomayananda

Original: 12.4 Having restrained all the senses, even-minded everywhere, intent on the welfare of all beings  verily they also come unto Me.
Translated: 12. 4 I am the one who receives the devotees who regularly regulate the sense community in the interests of all beings who are equal everywhere.

Original: 12.5 Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the unmanifested; for the goal; the unmanifested, is very hard for the embodied to reach.
Translated: 12. 5 But the men with the psyche attached to the impersonal are more troubled because the movement of the impersonal is difficult to obtain from the bodyguards. 12. 5

Original: 12.6 But to those who worship Me, renouncing all actions in Me, regarding Me as the supreme gaol, meditating on Me with single-minded Yoga.
Translated: But those devotees who consider me to be the ultimate goal, devote all their works to me, and pay attention to me by exclusive action.

Original: 12.7 To those whose minds are set on Me, O Arjuna, verily I become ere long the saviour out of the ocean of Samsara.
Translated: 12. 7. I am about to rescue the devotees of the dead from the sea of the world, O pilgrims, whose spirit is fixed in me.

Original: 12.8 Fix thy mind in Me only, thy intellect in Me, (then) thou shalt no doubt live in Me alone hereafter.
Translated: Fix your mind and your intelligence in me, and you shall dwell in me, there is no doubt about it.

Original: 12.9 If thou art unable to fix thy mind steadily on Me, then by the Yoga of constant practice do thou seek to reach Me, O Arjuna.
Translated: 12. 9. < s > If you are not able to stabilise your mind in me, wish to attain me by practicing Yoga.

Original: 12.10 If thou art unable to practise even this Abhyasa Yoga, be thou intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, thou shalt attain perfection.
Translated: 12. 10. If you are unable to practise, be a practitioner of miracles; in this way you will attain perfection even though you do things for me.

Original: 12.11 If thou art unable to do even this, then, resorting to union with Me, renounce the fruits of all actions with the self controlled.
Translated: And if you are unable to do this, then with self - restraint and with the help of Yoga, abandon the fruit of all your deeds.

Original: 12.12 Better indeed is knowledge than practice; than knowledge meditation is better; than meditation the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation.
Translated: 12. 12. Knowledge is better than practice; meditation is better than knowledge, and even meditation is better than work. renunciation is renunciation.

Original: 12.13 He who hates no creature, who is friendly and compassionate to all, who is free from attachment and egoism, balanced in pleasure and pain, and forgiving.
Translated: 12. 13. 2. He who is without envy to the past and friend and compassionate to all; who is free of affection and egoism, equal in happiness and evil and forgiving.

Original: 12.14 Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessed of firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devtoee, is dear to Me.
Translated: 12. 14. I love the restrained soul, the determined yogi who is always satisfied, who has devoted his mind and his intellect to me, who is my devotee.

Original: 12.15 He by whom the world is not agitated and who cannot be agitated by the world, and who is freed from joy, anger, fear and anxiety  he is dear to Me.
Translated: 12. 15. I love the devotee who does not get the enthusiasm of a people (i. e. a person) and who does not even feel the enthusiasm of a person himself and who is free from joy, bitterness (intolerance), fear and enthusiasm.

Original: 12.16 He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings or commencements  he who is (thus) devoted to Me, is dear to Me.
Translated: 12. 16. I love my devotee who is unparalleled, pure, skilled, indifferent, free and devout to all works.

Original: 12.17 He who neither rejoices, nor hates, nor grieves, nor desires, renouncing good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me.
Translated: 12. 17. I love the devout man who neither rejoices nor hates; neither mourns nor longs; and who forsakes good and evil.

Original: Swami Sivananda did not comment on this sloka
Translated: Swami Tejomayananda

Original: 12.19 He to whom censure and praise are eal, who is silent, content with anything, homeless, of a steady mind, and full of devotion  that man is dear to Me.
Translated: 12. 19. I love the devout man of static intellect, who is equal to both reproach and praise, who is silent, who is satisfied with nothing but a small thing, who is indefatigable.

Original: 12.20 They verily who follow this immortal Dharma (law or doctrine) as described above, endowed with faith, regarding Me as their supreme goal, they, the devotees, are exceedingly dear to Me.
Translated: I am very fond of those devotees who are devout and who think of me as the ultimate goal and follow this sacred nectar, the sacred life.

Original: 13.1 Arjuna said  I wish to learn about Nature (matter) and the Spirit (soul), the field and the knower of the field, knowledge and that which ought to be known, O Kesava.
Translated: Arjun said, "Hey Keshav, I want to know nature and man, the field and the field, and knowledge and knowledge.

Original: 13.2 The Blessed Lord said  This body, O Arjuna, is called the field; he who knows it is called the knower of the field, by those who know of them.
Translated: Sri Bhagwan said, "Hey, whoa! This body is called the field and he who knows it is called the elemental man, the fielder.

Original: 13.3 Do thou also know Me as the knower of the field in all fields, O Arjuna. Knowledge of both the field and the knower of the field is considered by Me to be ï1the ï1 knowledge.
Translated: I believe that the knowledge of the field and the knowledge of the field are the same.

Original: 13.4 What the field is and of what nature, what are its modifications and whence it is and also who He is and what His powers are  hear all that from Me in brief.
Translated: Therefore, listen to me briefly about what is and what is like and what has diseases, and what has happened because of what, and what is and what has influence.

Original: 13.5 Sages have sung in many ways, in various distinctive chants and also in the suggestive words indicative of the Absolute, full of reasoning and decisive.
Translated: 13. 5 - LRB - in the matter of field - field - scholar - RRB -, various and varied verses have been sung by the sages, and by the appropriately defined words of the rational Brahmo Sutra (i. e. the indicative words of Brahmo) - RRB -.

Original: 13.6 The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses and one (mind), and the five objects of the senses.
Translated: 12. 6. 12. Pancha Mahabhuta, ego, intellect, invisible (nature), ten senses, one mind, five subjects of senses.

Original: 13.7 Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (the body), intelligence, fortitude  the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.
Translated: 1.37. 32. Desire, hatred, happiness, sorrow, union (substantial doubt), consciousness (mindfulness of infinity) and tenacity - thus this area is briefly described including disorders.

Original: 13.8 Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service of the teacher, purity, steadfastness, self-control.
Translated: 1.38. 32. Amnesia, Immediacy, Nonviolence, Forgiveness, Advancing, Service to the Acharya, Purity, Stability and Self - Control.
